name: heat production, lignite briquette, at stove 5-15kW | heat, central or small-scale, other than natural gas | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/4510/documentation

This dataset represents the production of heat from a 5-15 kW coal stove filled with 1 MJ of lignite briquettes. The lifetime of the coal stove is 30 years, which corresponds to 1600 fully load hours per year. The heating value is 19.5 MJ/kg and the efficiency factor is 70%.;[This dataset was already contained in the ecoinvent database version 2. It was not individually updated during the transfer to ecoinvent version 3. Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. This dataset was generated following the ecoinvent quality guidelines for version 2. It may have been subject to central changes described in the ecoinvent version 3 change report (http://www.ecoinvent.org/database/ecoinvent-version-3/reports-of-changes/), and the results of the central updates were reviewed extensively. The changes added e.g. consistent water flows and other information throughout the database. The documentation of this dataset can be found in the ecoinvent reports of version 2, which are still available via the ecoinvent website. The change report linked above covers all central changes that were made during the conversion process.]

From reception of hard coal briquettes.

This activity ends with produced heat at the coal stove filled with 1 MJ of lignite briquettes. The dataset includes transport and all emissions to air as well as the ash disposal. The dataset doesn’t include emissions to water as it is assumed that the coal is stored in a covered storage area.
category: D:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/35:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/353:Steam and air conditioning supply/3530:Steam and air conditioning supply

processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Average technology installed in early 1990s. The efficiency factor of a coal stove is between 50% and 70%. Since the coal stove is installed in the room to be heated, losses occur especially through the large amounts of flue gas and through incomplete combustion. An efficiency factor of 70% is assumed. Since neither ventilators nor air supply pumps are required for hot water circulation, no auxiliary energy is needed.;Reference:;Braun H., Angrüner B., Ecker P., Gschaider R., Sorger A., Wurst F., Ellinger R. (1991) Emissionen bei der Verbennung. Wien.;DGMK-Arbeitskreis (1992) Ansatzpunkte und Potentiale zur Minderung des Treibhauseffektes aus Sicht der fossilen Energieträger. Hamburg.;Fritsche U., Rausch L., Simon K.-H. (1989) Umweltwirkungsanalyse von Energiesystemen: Gesamt-Emissions-Modell Integrierter Systeme (GEMIS). Darmstadt/Kassel, Deutschland.;Jensch W. (1988) Vergleich von Energiesystemen unterschiedlicher Zentralisierung. IfE-Schriftenreihe Heft 22, München.;Menke C., Leithner R. (1990) Auswirkung der Energieversorgung auf die Luftqualität in der Region Braunschweig. In: BWK, Band 42, Nr.7/8, s.446-456.

exchanges.description:
Amount was scaled to 1.
EcoSpold01Location=RER

flow.name: heat, central or small-scale, other than natural gas
flow.category: D:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/35:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/353:Steam and air conditioning supply/3530:Steam and air conditioning supply

exchanges.description:
Modeled, based on “heat production, coal, emissions to air” - pdf-document on the dedicated talk page of ecoinvent (www.ecoinvent.org/documentation). Size distribution of particles has been estimated on the basis of recent information from U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).
Amount was scaled to the amount of reference product.

flow.name: Particulate Matter, > 2.5 um and < 10um
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/high population density

exchanges.description:
Modeled, based on “heat production, coal, emissions to air” - pdf-document on the dedicated talk page of ecoinvent (www.ecoinvent.org/documentation). Emissions of trace elements were calculated using the ash content in the coal and average transfer coefficients for coal power plants with ash retention of 98 %.
Amount was scaled to the amount of reference product.

flow.name: Lead II
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/high population density

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=DE
Estimation. For the quality of lignite fuel data are available from Rheinbraun. The main elements represent annual averages. The caloric value is 19.5 MJ/kg, the bulk density is 710-750 kg/m3, the water content is 19% and the ash content is 4%. Further values are 53.2% of carbonate, 0.6% of nitrogen, 0.35% of sulfur, 0.0025% of chlorine, 0.001% of flour.
Amount was scaled to the amount of reference product.

exchanges.description:
Modeled, based on “heat production, coal, emissions to air” - pdf-document on the dedicated talk page of ecoinvent (www.ecoinvent.org/documentation). From radioactivity of the elements.
Amount was scaled to the amount of reference product.

flow.name: Thorium-228
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/high population density

exchanges.description:
Modeled, based on “heat production, coal, emissions to air” - pdf-document on the dedicated talk page of ecoinvent (www.ecoinvent.org/documentation). Emissions of trace elements were calculated using the ash content in the coal and average transfer coefficients for coal power plants with ash retention of 98 %.
Amount was scaled to the amount of reference product.

flow.name: Zinc II
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/high population density

exchanges.description:
Modeled, based on “heat production, coal, emissions to air” - pdf-document on the dedicated talk page of ecoinvent (www.ecoinvent.org/documentation). The emission data are taken from the literature reporting measurements performed at the end of the 1980s in Germany and are based on the composition of the coal.
Amount was scaled to the amount of reference product.
